resources.string: Photography Assistant provides exposure setting calculation and depth of field calculation. It can use the built-in ambient light sensor reading or manually set values to get Exposure Values.
Ambient light sensor, if your phone has one, could be very inaccurate. Manual exposure setting is preferred for accuracy.

To use the built-in light sensor, click the \"Auto EV\" radio button and check the status message, it will say something like "Using CM3602 Light sensor" if you have ambient light sensor on the phone. Then if you place the cell phone as you would place an incident light sensor, the screen is the front side. The shutter speed will then be calculated and displayed. Sometimes the ambient light sensor can be slow in response and you will see N/A as reading, in this case, move the cell phone to face different light situation will trigger the ambient light sensor to report new reading. You can use the lock button to lock the exposure value read from the ambient light sensor, just like what you can do with an incident light meter.

The manual exposure settings is actually more useful than the auto one. Because ambient light sensor, if your phone has one, is usually not accurate enough. With the help of the textual description, you probably can do a better job than the built-in ambient light sensors.

You can also calibrate the ambient light sensor. There is a calibration constant that affects how Exposure value is calculated from the illumination value read from the ambient light sensor. By calibration, you can help the app adjust this constant so that exposure value could be more accurate. To calibrate, place your phone in a light situation where you can easily tell the exposure value, then set the manual exposure setting to be that value. Then click menu -> Calibrate and click the calibrate button in the pop-up window. The app will then recalculate the calibration constant so that it will generate the same exposure value using the ambient light sensor\'s illumination reading.

There are 3 modes you can select to work with. Av (Aperture Priority), Sv (Shutter Priority) and M (Manual). Av is the very basic that we probably use most often. Sv can be used when shooting video. M is developed so that this app can work with other light meters. In M mode, this App is mainly for depth of field calculation.
